inference:
The first equation implies $x-1+1-x\equiv 0\pmod{12}$, so $2\equiv 0\pmod{12}$, which implies $x\equiv 1\pmod{6}$. The second equation implies $x-2+2-x\equiv 0\pmod{12}$, so $4\equiv 0\pmod{12}$, which implies $x\equiv 4\pmod{6}$. Since $x\equiv 1\pmod{6}$ and $x\equiv 4\pmod{6}$, we have $x\equiv 10\pmod{6}$, so $x=10$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{10}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
First, we simplify both of the congruence relationships to get:  \begin{align*}
&x-1\equiv 1-x\pmod {12}\implies 2x\equiv 2\pmod{12},\\
&x-2\equiv 2-x\pmod{12}\implies 2x\equiv 4\pmod{12}.
\end{align*}Since $2x$ cannot be equivalent to both 2 and 4 mod 12, we know that there are $\boxed{0}$ solutions.

Since $x\equiv 1\pmod{6}$ and $x\equiv 4\pmod{6}$, we have $x\equiv 10\pmod{6}$, so $x=10$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{10}$. I hope it is correct.
